;弗拉基米尔·普京总统继续努力重申其权威，并表现出一切如常的感觉瓦格纳雇佣兵的叛变威胁到了他在俄罗斯近四分之一个世纪的统治。

;

;普京定于周四在莫斯科举行的一个名为“新时代的强创意”的论坛上发表讲话，该论坛是一年一度的活动，其在瓦格纳领导人叶夫根尼·普里戈任的军队在距首都 200 公里（124 英里）范围内发动叛乱后，这个头衔具有了意想不到的象征意义。

;

;他的评论将受到密切关注，以了解是否涉及最近发生的事件。

;

; p>;

;总统连夜从俄罗斯南部达吉斯坦共和国返回莫斯科，在那里他与地区官员就促进旅游业发展进行了会谈。尽管一名官员感谢普京“在如此困难的时刻”到访，但并未提及周六的叛变。

;

;不同寻常的是，国家电视台显示普京与欢呼的当地居民混在一起，甚至亲吻了一名年轻女孩的头部并摆出姿势与她合影。这与克里姆林宫长期以来对任何与普京会面的人实行严格的Covid-19隔离制度形成鲜明对比，以避免这位70岁的领导人可能受到感染。

;

;尽管努力描绘叛变危机截至最后，关于军队和安全部门内部人员在多大程度上了解普里戈任计划进军莫斯科推翻国防部高级官员的问题仍然悬而未决。

;

;瓦格纳的全副武装的部队首先控制了俄罗斯南部城市顿河畔罗斯托夫，然后跨越780公里领土迅速向莫斯科进军，沿途封锁了军队部队，没有遇到重大抵抗。

;

;普里戈任只是叫停了前进在接受白俄罗斯总统亚历山大·卢卡申科斡旋的一项协议后，在对瓦格纳创始人或其战士的刑事指控被撤销后，他可以前往邻国。

;

;令人眼花缭乱的一系列事件已经离开了美国、欧洲中国对一场叛乱造成的政治后果感到困惑，这场叛乱粉碎了普京作为俄罗斯领导人的不可战胜的形象。

;

;这场危机凸显了俄罗斯内部因乌克兰战争而存在的激烈分歧，乌克兰战争是二战以来欧洲最大的冲突，乌克兰的反攻继续试图将普京的军队赶出被占领土。

;美国最高法院周四驳回了哈佛大学具有种族意识的学生招生计划和北卡罗来纳大学的平权行动政策遭受了严重挫折，这些政策通常用于增加校园中黑人、西班牙裔和其他代表性不足的少数群体的数量。

;

;法官做出了有利于一个名为“由反平权行动活动家爱德华·布鲁姆 (Edward Blum) 创立的“学生公平招生”组织，对下级法院维持两所著名学校为培养多元化学生群体而使用的项目的裁决提出上诉。

;

;该决定由法院的保守派法官与持不同意见的自由派法官，以 6 比 3 战胜北卡罗来纳大学，以 6 比 2 战胜哈佛大学。自由派法官 Ketanji Brown Jackson 没有参与哈佛案件。

;

;在去年同样由保守派法官牵头的重大裁决中，法院推翻了 1973 年罗伊诉韦德案的裁决，该裁决使堕胎在全国范围内合法化并扩大了枪支范围两项具有里程碑意义的裁决中的权利。

;

;首席大法官约翰·罗伯茨（John Roberts）代表多数派撰文表示，“哈佛和北卡罗来纳大学的招生计划无法与平等保护条款的保证相一致”，他指的是美国宪法的承诺法律下的平等保护。

;

;“与此同时，”罗伯茨说，“正如各方都同意的那样，本意见中的任何内容均不应被解释为禁止大学考虑申请人关于种族如何影响的讨论布鲁姆的团队在 2014 年提起的诉讼中指控北卡罗来纳大学歧视白人和亚裔美国申请者，以及哈佛大学对亚裔美国申请者存在偏见。 .

;

;学生公平招生组织声称，公立大学北卡罗来纳大学采取的非种族中立的招生政策违反了宪法第十四修正案对法律平等保护的保证。

;

; >;

;该组织认为哈佛大学是一所私立大学，违反了具有里程碑意义的联邦法律《1964 年民权法案》第六章，该法案禁止在接受联邦财政援助的任何计划或活动中基于种族、肤色或国籍的歧视。< /p>;

;许多高等教育机构、企业和军队领导人长期以来一直支持校园平权行动，不仅是为了纠正美国生活中的种族不平等和排斥现象，也是为了确保人才库能够为工作场所带来多种观点和美国武装部队军衔。

;

;根据哈佛大学的数据，大约 40% 的美国学院和大学以某种方式考虑种族问题。

;

;哈佛大学和北卡罗来纳大学表示，他们仅将种族问题视为一个因素考虑到对无配额录取的一系列个性化评估（最高法院之前的判例是允许的），并且限制其考虑将导致代表性不足群体的学生入学率大幅下降。

;

;美国的平权行动大学不公平，尤其是对亚裔美国人

;

;几十年来一直试图推翻这些政策的批评者认为，这些政策本身就是歧视性的。

;

;许多美国保守派和共和党民选官员认为无论动机或情况如何，给予某一种族优势都是违宪的。

;

;一些人提出了不再需要补救性优惠的论点，因为美国已经超越了过去的种族主义政策，例如种族隔离和变得越来越多样化。

;

;这场纠纷为最高法院的保守派多数派提供了推翻其先前允许种族意识招生政策的裁决的机会。

;

;下级法院驳回了该组织的主张，引发了上诉向美国最高法院要求法官推翻一个重要先例，即大学可以将种族作为招生过程中的一个因素，因为创建多元化的学生群体具有迫切的兴趣。

;

;“没有解决这个问题问题：马来西亚的土著政策，五十年来

;

;平权行动几十年来经受住了最高法院的审查，最近一次是在 2016 年一项涉及一名白人学生的裁决中，该裁决得到了布鲁姆的支持，布鲁姆在被起诉后起诉了德克萨斯大学

;

;最高法院自 2016 年以来向右转，现在包括对德克萨斯大学案件持异议的三名法官以及前共和党总统唐纳德·特朗普任命的三名新法官。

;欧盟领导人周四齐聚一堂，讨论俄罗斯流产的兵变，并讨论其角色欧盟可以履行西方加强乌克兰安全的长期承诺。

;

;领导人在抵达布鲁塞尔参加峰会时表示，他们仍然致力于支持乌克兰应对去年 2 月俄罗斯入侵其邻国引发的战争德国总理奥拉夫·肖尔茨 (Olaf Scholz) 对记者表示：“我们必须做好准备，这种情况会持续很长时间。”

;

;“重要的是，我们要进行磋商并表示我们正在准备长期坚持下去，提供乌克兰所必需的财政和人道主义支持，而且在武器方面也是如此。”他说。

;

;北约秘书长延斯·斯托尔滕贝格与领导人共进工作午餐并预计乌克兰总统泽连斯基也将通过视频连线在峰会上发表讲话。

;

;为期两天的峰会是欧盟 27 国领导人的定期聚会，议题包括移民、经济安全和关系等一系列议题与中国的一切都提上了议程。

;

;但主要话题是乌克兰战争，领导人还讨论了上周末瓦格纳雇佣军组织流产的叛变可能如何影响俄罗斯。

;

;领导人表示，他们将密切关注瓦格纳领导人叶夫根尼·普里戈任被流放的白俄罗斯。

;

;一些人还表示，兵变削弱了普京的实力，但这并不意味着西方可以放松。

;

;“普京的削弱是一个更大的危险，”欧盟外交政策负责人何塞普·博雷尔表示。 “不稳定的俄罗斯也会成为一种风险。”

;

;许多领导人强调，叛乱是俄罗斯内部事务，无论如何，欧盟都应该继续支持乌克兰。

;

;随着西方国家制定一揽子长期保证措施，向基辅提供武器、装备、弹药、训练和其他军事援助，这种援助也在布鲁塞尔的谈判桌上提出。

;

;峰会结论草案表示欧盟及其成员国已准备好为未来对乌克兰的安全承诺做出贡献，“帮助乌克兰长期保卫自己，威慑侵略行为并抵制破坏稳定的努力”。

;

;外交官们表示，法国 –欧盟发挥更大安全作用的拥护者提出了该文本，称其想法是建立在欧盟举措的基础上，例如为基辅提供军事援助的基金和乌克兰士兵的培训任务。

;

;但该案文引起了奥地利、爱尔兰、马耳他和塞浦路斯等军事上不结盟的欧盟成员国以及波罗的海国家等跨大西洋合作坚定支持者的担忧，这些国家坚称欧洲安全主要是北约的事务。

;

;俄罗斯的高级将领在哪里？瓦格纳叛变后谣言四起

;

;“对于我们作为中立国来说，很明显我们不能提供这样的安全保证。奥地利、爱尔兰、马耳他和塞浦路斯已明确表示反对，”奥地利总理卡尔·内哈默在参加峰会的路上说道。

;

;“我们肯定会讨论这个问题，我们会找到可以接受的方案对我们来说也是如此。”

;

;包括美国、英国、法国和德国在内的国家正在讨论下个月在立陶宛维尔纽斯举行的北约峰会之前为乌克兰提供的可能的安全保证。

;

;荷兰首相马克·吕特表示，欧盟的任何角色仍有待讨论。

;

;“我们必须讨论它能走多远，以及是致命还是非致命支持。我们必须考虑到一些欧盟国家不是北约成员国。”吕特说。

;

;乌克兰：基辅指控当地男子指挥导弹袭击，造成 10 人死亡

;

;同时，在有报道称俄罗斯瓦格纳雇佣兵计划转移到邻国白俄罗斯后，波兰计划加强其东部边境。

;

;波兰副总理雅罗斯瓦夫·卡钦斯基周三晚间表示，将增加军装部队和“保护防御工事”

;

;卡钦斯基是在政府安全与国防问题委员会特别会议后发表上述评论的。他援引波兰情报称，多达 8,000 名瓦格纳战士可以在白俄罗斯避难。

;

;波兰是欧盟和北约成员国，与白俄罗斯有 418 公里（260 英里）的边界。 2021 年夏末和秋季，边境局势升级，数千人试图非法进入欧盟。

;

;欧盟指责白俄罗斯领导人亚历山大·卢卡申科将移民从危机地区带到欧盟有组织地对外边界向西方施压。此后，波兰在边境陆地部分安装了 5.5 米高的围栏。

;

;普里戈任周六暂时占领了俄罗斯南部城市顿河畔罗斯托夫，然后率领他的战士前往莫斯科，瓦格纳首领与莫斯科军事领导层之间长期酝酿的权力斗争升级。

;

;距离俄罗斯首都约200公里，武装起义突然中止。

;

;卢卡申科据称，普里戈任调解了这次叛变，据报道，普里戈任和他的雇佣兵承诺免受俄罗斯总统弗拉基米尔·普京的起诉。

;

;据卢卡申科称，普里戈任现在在白俄罗斯。白俄罗斯强人还允许雇佣军战士进入他的国家。

;

;

;A woman's leg had to be amputated in a Thai airport after it was trapped by a moving walkway on Thursday, officials said.

;

;The 57-year-old Thai passenger was due to board a morning flight from Bangkok's Don Mueang Airport to the southern Nakhon Si Thammarat province when she was caught by the walkway in the airport's Terminal 2.

;

;A medical team eventually had to cut her left leg off from above the knee, according to airport officials.

;

;“On behalf of the Don Mueang International Airport, I'd like to express my deepest condolences regarding the accident,” Don Mueang Airport Director Karun Thanakuljeerapat said during a press conference. “I'd like to insist that we will ensure that no such accident will happen again.”

;

;He said the airport will be fully responsible for the woman's medical costs and will be open to negotiations on other compensation.

;

;The medical team at the hospital she was initially sent to informed Karun that they could not reattach her leg, but the woman requested to be transferred to another hospital to assess the possibility, he said.

;

;Images shared online showed the lower part of the woman's leg trapped beneath the belt at the end of the walkway as she was being assisted by airport staff.

;

;A suitcase lying near her was missing two wheels, and yellow comb-like plates were seen broken off from where they typically cover the edge of the belt where the moving walkway ends.

;

;Karun said the suitcase wheels were found underneath the belt, but it was unclear how it might relate to the accident. He said walkways at the airport are checked daily, with an additional monthly inspection. He said the walkway has been closed and a team of engineers was inspecting it to determine the cause of the accident.

;

;The walkway was manufactured by Japanese company Hitachi and was installed in 1996, the airport director said, adding that there is a plan to request for a budget to change to a newer model in 2025.

;

;In 2019, a passenger's shoe was damaged after it was caught in the airport's moving walkway in Terminal 1. The airport released a statement after that saying the faulty walkway was repaired and reopened in about an hour.

; Thu, 29 Jun 2023 21:20:02 +0800 South Korean tech giant Samsung skips MWC Shanghai 2023 trade show for unknown reasons in break from annual participationhttps://www.scmp.com/tech/big-tech/article/3225895/south-korean-tech-giant-samsung-skips-mwc-shanghai-2023-trade-show-unknown-reasons-break-annual?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.06.29 21:00;

;Samsung Electronics, the world's largest smartphone vendor, was conspicuously absent for unknown reasons at MWC Shanghai, the regional edition of the world's biggest mobile communications industry trade show, in a break from the company's annual participation.

;

;The South Korean tech conglomerate's absence at the three-day MWC Shanghai, which returned as an in-person event this year and concludes this Friday, marks the first time the company has not taken part in the annual trade show since at least 2017, according to public information on its website. Samsung even had a booth at MWC Shanghai during the event's pandemic-marred 2021 edition.

;

;By contrast, Seoul-based Samsung – which remained the top global smartphone vendor in the first quarter and the whole of 2022, according to research firm IDC – had eight stands at MWC Barcelona 2023, organiser GSM Association's (GSMA) flagship annual mobile industry trade show, which was held from February 27 to March 2 in the capital of Spain's autonomous community of Catalonia.

;

;Samsung did not immediately respond to requests for comment since Wednesday. MWC Shanghai organiser GSMA, which represents the interests of mobile network operators worldwide, said it had no response to Samsung's absence.

;

;Still, there were other major industry stalwarts that did not exhibit at this year's MWC Shanghai.

;

;Swedish telecommunications equipment maker Ericsson and US-based Qualcomm – a developer of semiconductors, software and services related to mobile communications – also did not have booths at the Shanghai event this year, according to a representative from GSMA.

;

;Ericsson planned to set up a booth at MWC Shanghai, but then “backed out” just before the event opened this week, according to the representative who declined to be named. Qualcomm was initially booked as an exhibitor, but later decided to cancel for reasons unknown to the trade show's organiser.

;

;But unlike Samsung, both Ericsson and Qualcomm were included among MWC Shanghai's 15 major corporate sponsors. Senior executives from the two firms were also among the featured speakers at the event.

;

;MWC Shanghai returns as in-person event after 2-year pandemic hiatus

;

;Samsung's no-show at MWC Shanghai has come at a time of rising tensions between China and South Korea.

;

;Relations between Seoul and Beijing have soured since the South Korean government denounced China for committing a “serious diplomatic discourtesy” after a Chinese official said recent comments by President Yoon Suk-yeol on Taiwan amounted to verbal meddling, according to Yonhap News.

;

;Ties between the two countries have never fully recovered after China opposed the US deployment of the Terminal High Altitude Area anti-missile defence system about six years ago.

;

;The once-formidable trade in semiconductors between China and South Korea also continued to decline in May, according to the latest data from Beijing and Seoul, amid geopolitical tensions that have changed the chip supply chain landscape in Asia.

;

;China-South Korea tech trade slumps in May amid changes in chip supply chain

;

;The diminishing tech trade, particularly in semiconductors, between the two countries comes after China's standing in the global chip supply chain was affected by Seoul's decision to closely align its interests with Tokyo and Washington.

;

;South Korea forms part of the US government-backed Chip 4 Alliance that includes Japan and Taiwan. Beijing has criticised this coalition as a plot by Washington to exclude China from semiconductor supply chains.

;

;Chinese technology companies, meanwhile, seized the limelight at MWC Shanghai, making up for the absence of some major foreign companies.

;

;Huawei Technologies Co, for example, was one of the largest exhibitors at the trade show and also an event sponsor. The Shenzhen-based company's 1,500-square-metre booth attracted large crowds, as the firm exhibited its latest 5G products and intelligent digital transformation systems.

;

;Huawei, Chinese telecoms firms tout 5G as life-changing tech at MWC Shanghai

;

;ZTE Corp had a 1,100-square-metre booth at the trade show, where it displayed its latest information and communications technology hardware products and applications.

;

;A delegate from US semiconductor company Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) said China remains “very important” to the company, despite external uncertainties.

;

;“Compared with the Barcelona event we just attended, the size of the Shanghai event is smaller but the technology is more ahead as China continues to drive innovation,” said Gilles Garcia, a senior director at AMD's data centre and communications group.

;

;A total of 300 exhibitors from across the globe took part in MWC Shanghai at the Shanghai International Expo Centre. The event, which marked its first decade in China, was expected to attract 3,000 visitors, according to London-based GSMA.

; Thu, 29 Jun 2023 21:20:02 +0800 Taiwan to test airport defence for first time in annual Han Kuang exerciseshttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/military/article/3225980/taiwan-test-airport-defence-first-time-annual-han-kuang-exercises?utm_source=rss_feed

;Taiwan's military will stage a drill at the island's main international airport for the first time next month, practising defence of the facility in a cross-strait war.

;

;The drill, to be held at Taoyuan International Airport south of Taipei on July 26, is part of the Han Kuang exercises – the island's major annual war games.

;

;It will be the first time the airport has been used for a military drill since it opened in 1979.

;

;The drill will test the readiness of the island's troops to repel an airborne assault, including forces parachuted in by the People's Liberation Army, according to Taiwan's defence ministry.

;

;“Members of the Aviation and Special Forces Command and Army Airborne Special Forces will pose as the invading forces to be repelled by the ground troops,” a ministry official said on Thursday.

;

;The official said the drill would last about an hour, with rehearsals on July 12 and 19.

;

;The ministry had already notified the airport and relevant authorities of the exercise and the preparations, including closure of part of the airport and flight rescheduling.

;

;Airport officials said flights would be suspended for two hours because the military needed time to prepare for the drill and the airport needed to manage the resumption of traffic.

;

;“The north runway and part of the south runway will be closed down from 9am to 11am on July 26 and also on July 12 and 19,” an airport official said, adding air traffic control notices would be issued to all airlines for coordination and flight rearrangements.

;

;As the facility was busy during the summer travel season, the official asked for understanding from customers.

;

;“We have estimated that more than 65 flights and 4,000 travellers will be affected during the exercise on July 26,” the official said, adding this also applied to the two rehearsals on July 12 and 19.

;

;The unprecedented inclusion of the airport – the island's major gateway to the world – in the exercise was apparently the result of a proposal by a group of US experts following their observation of the Han Kuang Exercise last year, according to local news media.

;

;Military experts said the drill was necessary because Taoyuan airport was just 3km (1.9 miles) from Zhuwei beach – one of the “red beaches” on the island that PLA forces could target for a landing and swift access to the island's capital of Taipei.

;

;In his 2017 book The Chinese Invasion Threat, Ian Easton says that while most of the island's coastal regions would present serious challenges, 14 of these beaches would likely allow potential enemies to establish a beachhead.

;

;Shuai Hua-min, a retired army lieutenant general, said: “If the Chinese communists choose to land at Zhuwei beach, they definitely will push their forces further north to take over Taoyuan airport so that they can transport troops and weapons to Taiwan.”

;

;He said the PLA would need the airport to support its air-sea-surface operations, involving the navy's amphibious force and landing craft and its air force's paratroopers.

;

;Shuai said that from the airport, the PLA could send forces to attack Taipei in less than an hour.

;

;Shu Hsiao-huang, an analyst of the Institute for National Defence and Security Research, a government-funded think tank in Taipei, said that if the PLA intended to attack Taiwan, it would not destroy all of the island's air and sea ports because it would need continuous supplies and troops for its operations.

;

;“Capturing Taoyuan airport thus became an important mission for the PLA,” he said, adding that was why the island's military needed to familiarise itself with the airport.

;

;He said the Taiwanese military was not familiar with the airport all because it had never staged any anti-airborne and anti-takeover drills at the facility.

;The latest data from the authority found it received 519 complaints related to scams and financial crimes between January and May. The city's de facto central bank recorded 555 incidents in 2022.

;

;Among the complaints received during the first five months of this year, 382 involved unauthorised credit card transactions. The authority only recorded 391 such cases last year.

;

;Police figures show 1,408 victims had fallen prey to phishing scams during the first three months of the year, losing a total of HK$26.1 million (US$3.3 million).

;

;

;Arthur Yuen Kwok-hang, the authority's deputy chief executive, on Thursday urged residents to make sure they only carried out online transactions on official platforms and to be wary when submitting their personal details over the internet.

;

;“When conducting any kind of transaction, please ensure you are logged into the official platform via formal channels before completing the transaction. Don't try to log in via hyperlinks,” he said as he moderated a panel of industry representatives.

;

;“Please also verify the identity of the counterparty [during online transactions] and be careful about sensitive information such as personal details, credit card information and one-time passwords. Do not hand them over to the other party.”

;

;Representatives for a local bank and two major merchants said customers should look out for phishing messages that used official-looking email addresses and offered fake discounts.

;

;The panel also urged residents to check the email addresses of suspicious requests for unpaid postage fees or to collect packages, as well as those notifying recipients of lottery prizes or impersonating major businesses in the city.
